title: Can we just get rid of the concept of "DPS Mage"
body:
Because let's face it, when they are good...they're not just DPSing you. With AP itemization, they're BURSTING you while also DPSing tanks down instantly. Now I understand the argument that ADC's do this, too, and that's true. A full build ADC is going to kill any squishy target relatively quickly, too. But the difference here is AP's have access to itemization that grants them durability, utility, CDR and invulnerability - while still getting offense through their build pathing. 

To prove my point, just look at Azir, Ryze and Cass. When they're good, they ARE DPSing but they're also 100-0ing teams with burst as well, so it's a stupid mixture because it's both burst and DPS and with AP itemization, they gain utility AND they become harder to kill.

First of all, there's very little difference between CDR and Attack Speed if you're comparing a DPS mage to a DPS marksman.  Auto attacks are the primary damage of an AD marksman so attack speed is essentially just lowering the cooldown on their primary damage ability.

And durability?  ADCs get lifesteal, dps mages do not.  That's an extremely large benefit.  Mages are also far more limited by mana than ADCs as a general rule.  In the lategame this may not appear to matter as much, but after a big teamfight a mage has to recall because they're low on hp and mana, while a marksman will have half their mana left and get all their hp back by autoing a jungle camp 5 times allowing them to stay on the map and pressure an objective.

So sure, if you think Zhonyas is better durability than a bloodthirster then maybe you're right.  Personally I'd rather have an AP bloodthirster in my mage build and give up the active though.

And I'm not sure what you mean by utility.  If you're referring to aspects of their kit (Azir ult, for example) then that's not really comparable because ADCs all have different kits anyways.  You can't really compare an Azir ult to a Graves or a Caitlyn ult (and hell, let's just mention the utility in a Kalista ult) because they both have completely different purposes and both offer different kinds of utility.  If you're talking about itemization utility, dps mages have none of that because they don't get to build support items like twin shadows and banner of command.

DPS Mages are meant to be a Magic Damage equivalent of AD Carries. The issue with this, though, is that unlike AD Carries they don't deal their primary damage through Auto-Attacks (with some exceptions). They can potentially hit you with 3/4 abilities simultaneously. AD Carries don't actually have that option. For the most part AD Carry abilities revolve around 1. Poking, 2. Mobility and 3. finishing someone off.

Sustained AP DPS is basically - "fire as many abilities as I can as often as I can".

Cass and Karthus are probably the closest things to balanced DPS mages in the game because they have no real burst. They can deal upfront damage, but a lot of their kit revolves around quickly using their spam abilities then immediately repositioning.

The only real difference between, say, Ashe and Cassiopeia is that Riot intentionally wants Cass's ult to scale with her itemization, and Ashe's ultimate to not scale with her itemization.

Xerath, Orianna and Azir, for example, aren't DPS mages - they're mages with low cooldown compound-burst (one ability doesn't hurt much, but 2-3 at once will do anywhere between 1/2 and 3/4 of someone's health if they've not been completely shut down).

Theres two arguments I see here. One is about DPS mages playing APC and doing just as much or more damage than adc's - or at least with more upfront burst - while maintaining the utility a mage possesses. The other is simply that AP itemization is overpowered, facilitating damage growth on par with AD items while also given extra utility/defense.

For DPS mages, they do possess utility, but you can't tell me adc's don't as well. Or mobility or self peel. Vayne, Sivir, Ashe, Graves, Tristana, they all have kits with things in them besides damage. They're much more frequently mobile while mages have more cc.

I take exception to the example of Azir, because in my opinion he's overpowered. Yes, he's too good at everything and he doesn't have any weakness besides the skill people keep telling me it takes to play him.

But as to the AP items, I don't think they keep up with adc dps unless you build the pure damage ones. Stacking the dps multiplers of damage, attack speed, crit, and %armor pen is how adc's damage can explode as their gold does, while defenses can only multiply armor and hp and maybe some attack speed slow. Mages can get AP, %mpen, procs, and CDR. But only if they're building these damage focused AP items.

Many important details are left out of this definitely unbiased anecdote.  Did the "tank" build well?  How fed is the mage?  Does the problem extend beyond the 3 cherry picked examples?  The "when they're good" conditional is just a sneaky way to make this a No True Scotsman argument.  "Oh, well if your anecdote disagrees with my anecdote, it must be because the mages you're seeing are all bad"  Aside from obviously being a weak argument, it's one that can easily be turned back on the person who makes it:  "if teams are getting burst down by a mage, they're bad for grouping/building mobafire builds/etc".

I'll agree Riot does a poor job of making mages pay for their utility, but you'd have a hard time convincing me that a mage whose kit actually focuses on damage instead is doing too much damage (Karthus, for instance).  I also find it funny that people still balk at the suggestion of running anything but ADC in the duo lane, even though mages have these advantages you've mentioned over ADC.  Surely there's either something big these mages are missing or players are too stuck in their ways to adopt an actually good idea.  As for Riot's failure to correctly budget power in kits, especially when it's distributed across many different strengths:  that's true in all roles, just look at CertainlyT's champions and most of the new releases.

Not really.  She needs to get ahead to snowball or she needs a team to forget about her.  She has very little mobility (1 speed up now) and is extremely susceptible to cc and kiting, as she needs to poison someone to destroy them.  Her ult makes this easier, but most assassins can take her down without too much of a hassle, she's just got the DPS to be good in the current meta, but still often can't get ahead because the very tanks she melts can cc her for the opposing mid laner.  High DPS doesn't mean OP, it just means that she'll excel in a drawn out fight while mid laners like Katarina or Leblanc will be happier to wait out her ult and go in for the insta-burst before running out (unless kata gets a kill, then she just bursts some more).  Cass struggles against a lot of mid laners and is very mana hungry early plus suffers from being extremely easy to gank if she ever gets to pushing her lane.  Her power is mostly in team fights, and if your team cant win those, split-pushing or getting some picks is always a good option.
